docs.lead_paragraph: With the election six days away, the airwaves have become cluttered with political advertisements as the three candidates for governor jockey for position in the home stretch. So far, however, the blizzard of ads seems not to have changed the dynamic of the race, strategists say. Tom Golisano, the Independence Party candidate, running third in most polls, wants people disillusioned with government to believe that only he can beat Gov. George E. Pataki, whom he derides as a corrupt captive of special interests.

headline.main: Political Memo; A Storm of Political Ads Hits Race to Little Effect

docs.abstract: New York State gubernatorial race results seem established in days leading up to election, with numbers remaining relatively consistent despite barrage of television and radio ads assaulting voters (M)
docs.snippet: With the election six days away, the airwaves have become cluttered with political advertisements as the three candidates for governor jockey for position in the home stretch. So far, however, the blizzard of ads seems not to have changed the dynamic...

docs.lead_paragraph: American officials said yesterday that they suspected the Russian security police who raided a Moscow theater early Saturday might have used an aerosol version of a powerful, fast-acting opiate called Fentanyl to knock out Chechen extremists and prevent them from killing the 750 hostages they were holding. The gas killed 117 hostages, all but one of those who died in the Russian assault to retake the theater.

headline.main: U.S. Suspects Opiate in Gas In Russia Raid
headline.kicker: HOSTAGE DRAMA IN MOSCOW: THE TOXIC AGENT

docs.abstract: American officials suspect Russian security police who raided Moscow theater to rescue hostages seized by Chechen guerrillas probably used aerosol version of powerful, fast-acting opiate called Fentanyl to knock out Chechen extremists and prevent them from killing 750 people they were holding; say suspicions are tentative, since Russian officials have refused to provide information; say agent is probably similar to one of small arsenal of nonlethal weapons being quietly studied by US for use by soldiers and police officers against terrorists; scientists say US has conducted research on Fentanyl, well-known drug with many medical applications, as human incapacitant for nearly decade; gas killed 117 hostages; one hostage died in Russian assault to retake theater; photos (M)
docs.snippet: American officials said yesterday that they suspected the Russian security police who raided a Moscow theater early Saturday might have used an aerosol version of a powerful, fast-acting opiate called Fentanyl to knock out Chechen extremists and...

byline.original: By JUDITH MILLER and WILLIAM J. BROAD

docs.lead_paragraph: SOMETIMES a job pays well but perhaps not well enough. While other health care positions go begging because nurses and others feel that they are being paid too little to care for too many patients, pharmacy has generally been viewed as a lucrative and attractive profession. But many hospitals and clinics, in addition to drugstores and retailers, are struggling to find pharmacists. Although pharmacists, even right out of school, can earn about $80,000 a year, industry executives say it remains a challenge to find licensed people. There are about 200,000 licensed pharmacists in the United States. About two-thirds fill prescriptions and dispense advice to patients in drugstores, supermarkets or other retailers. An additional 25 percent work in hospitals and nursing homes. An increasing number are women, many of whom prefer to work part time.

headline.main: Available Spaces Behind The Prescription Counter

docs.abstract: Many hospitals and clinics, in addition to drugstores and retailers, are struggling to find pharmacists; although pharmacists, even right out of school, can earn $80,000 a year, industry executives say it remains challenge to find licensed people at time when more prescriptions are being written, result of large aging population and increasing availability of more medications; pharmacy can take as long as six years to train for the profession, and there is widespread concern that pharmacists have little opportunity to advance; photo (Special Section, Working) (M)
